'''Dudley Vivian Peyton-Ward''' CBE ( - 1976<ref>{{London gazette |issue=46968 |startpage=10000 |date=20 July 1976}}</ref>) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer who served in both the First World War and during and after the [[Second World War]].
‘P.W.’ to those that knew him, he was most famous for his work as Naval Liaison Officer to [[RAF Coastal Command]].<ref name="Hendrie 2006, p50">Hendrie 2006, p.50.</ref> The work he performed in this capacity was of utmost importance to the smooth functioning of Coastal Command operations, tactics and weapons (see: [[RAF Coastal Command#Weapons|Coastal Command weapon development]]. Among other things, he personally championed and facilitated the increased use of Very Long Range aircraft, such as the [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator]]. These aircraft allowed continual air cover over the Atlantic and closed the notorious [[Mid-Atlantic gap]], where Axis [[U-Boats]] could freely operate against Allied convoys.
It was said of him that he was the only person of lower than [[Air Marshal]] rank whose portrait appeared in the [[mess]] at Coastal Command.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1N8tAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA754&dq=peyton-ward+raf&hl=en&sa=X&ei=k-gcUYmsB8HJ0AXwloDQAg&ved=0CF8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=peyton-ward%20raf&f=false Air Estimates] 10 March 1955</ref>
After the war he wrote an eight-volume internal history for the Royal Navy, entitled ''The R.A.F. in the Maritime War'',<ref>http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/UN/UK/RAF.html</ref> a copy of which resides at [[The National Archives]] in [[Kew]], London. The preface to the British [[Official history]] of the RAF in the Second World (a supplemental work to the ''[[History of the Second World War]]'') says "Our debt is especially heavy to the Air Historical Branch: to its narrators—among them Captain D. V. Peyton-Ward, C.B.E., R.N. (retd.), perhaps more than any".<ref>http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/UN/UK/UK-RAF-I/UK-RAF-I-Preface.html</ref>
==Life== In May 1914 he was his sub-Lieutenancy was confirmed.<ref>http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/28828/pages/3663/page.pdf</ref> While a Lieutenant he was mentioned in dispatches in 1917 for "recognition of their services in submarines in enemy waters" during the First World War.<ref>{{London gazette|startpage=2290 |supp=yes |date=5 November 1917 |issue=13162 |city=e}}</ref>
In 1944 was named as a Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]].<ref>http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36544/supplements/2572/page.pdf</ref> After the war he was named officer of the US [[Legion of Merit]] for his contribution to the Allied cause during the war.<ref>{{London gazette |issue=37582 |supp=yes |startpage=2559 |date=24 May 1946 }}</ref>
